thread.title: Eddie Izzard urges North East young people to register to vote in the EU referendum
thread.title_full: Eddie Izzard urges North East young people to register to vote in the EU referendum

author: Hannah Graham
title: Eddie Izzard urges North East young people to register to vote in the EU referendum

organizations.name: eddie izzard stand up for europe

text:
Eddie Izzard urges North East young people to register to vote in the EU referendum 20:12, 6 Jun 2016 20:12, 6 Jun 2016 By Hannah Graham Comedian makes his plea with just hours to go to the register deadline and warns those who don't that 'old people' will decide their future Shares Get daily news by email Eddie Izzard Stand Up For Europe 
Comedian Eddie Izzard said the joke could be on young people in the North East if they don’t register to vote in the forthcoming European Referendum. 
The deadline to register in the June 23 ballot is midnight tomorrow . 
And Izzard said: “Young people of the North East: you have just one day left to register to vote in the EU Referendum. If you don’t register by midnight on Tuesday June 7, old people will decide your future. 
“It is vital you take part in this once-in-a-generation vote because this is your tomorrow, you will be most affected by the outcome. 
According to Bite the Ballot, a campaigning group urging young people to get involved in politics, people aged 18-24 are twice as likely not to be signed up to vote than the rest of the public. 
This is important, campaigners say, because the group has different concerns which should be represented. 
Bite the Ballot research suggests that the most important issue for under 30s when discussing Brexit was the impact leaving might have on health, with immigration and housing close second and third. 
A survey conducted by pollsters Opinium, for the Observer, found that in the 18-34 age group, 53% of people backed staying in, against 29% who wanted to leave. 
But only just over half (52%) in this age group said they were certain to actually go out and vote. Rui Vieira/PA Wire A voter placing a ballot paper in the ballot box 
By contrast older people were both more likely to want to leave the EU, with 54% of the over-55s wanting out, and more likely to be registered. 
Izzard, a vocal supporter of the Remain campaign, added: “It would be unfair on an entire generation if the UK is taken out of Europe against their wishes simply because your name was missing from the electoral roll. 
“You can register online now and make sure you can exercise your democratic right on June 23.” 
Efforts to persuade the younger generation to have its say have swept social media, with Twitter and Facebook both launching campaigns to remind users to sign up. 
Bite the Ballot also teamed up with cafe chain Starbucks in what it called an effort to “17th Century coffee house tradition” by encouraging people under 25 to come together in the shops to discuss referendum-related issues. Poll loading … 
The campaign group is even targeting youngsters while they’re looking for love, teaming up with dating app Tinder to urge users to take a break from swiping right on potential dates to learn more about the referendum and sign up to vote. 
Students are also being targeted particularly, as many may not be registered to vote at the address where they will be on polling day. 
Although, like everyone else, they can only cast one vote, students who aren’t sure if they’ll be at home or university on the 23rd are able to register at both their home and term-time addresses. 
Find out everything you need to know about registering to vote, as well as voting by post or proxy, here: http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/news/north-east-news/everything-you-need-know-registering-11417402
